questions.text: All of the following deoxynucleotides are present in DNA except
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • DNA's four monomeric deoxynucleotides are deoxyadenylate, deoxyguanylate, deoxycytidylate, and
  • Deoxyuridylate is not incorporated into DNA; uracil is found only in RNA.
  • These DNA nucleotides are linked by 3'→5' phosphodiester bonds to form each strand.
  • Thymidylate is deoxythymidine monophosphate carrying thymine's methylated base, which is critical for DNA stability and repair. (Option B)
  • Deoxyguanylate is deoxyguanosine monophosphate, containing guanine, which participates in canonical G-C base pairing and can form secondary structures like G-quadruplexes. (Option C)
  • Deoxycytidylate is deoxycytidine monophosphate carrying cytosine, whose deamination to uracil in DNA is recognised and corrected by base-excision repair. (Option D)

questions.text: Which of the following bonds do not involve the N base in the formation of bonds?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Phosphodiester bonds do not involve N bases in bond formation.
  • The phosphodiester bond joins the 3' hydroxyl group of deoxyribose of one nucleotide to the 5' hydroxyl group of another nucleotide through a phosphate group.
  • All deoxyribonucleotides are linked together by a 3' - 5' phosphodiester bond in the DNA strand.
  • The two strands of this double-stranded helix are held together by hydrogen bonds between the purine and pyrimidine bases of the respective linear molecules.
  • The pairings between the purine and pyrimidine nucleotides on the opposite strands are very specific and are dependent on hydrogen bonding of A with T and G with C (often referred to as Watson-Crick base pairs).

Three hydrogen bonds hold the deoxyguanosine nucleotide to the deoxycytidine nucleotide, whereas the other pair, the A-T pair, is held together by two hydrogen bonds. (Option A ruled out)

The two strands of this double-stranded helix are also held together by Van Der Waals and hydrophobic interactions between the stacked adjacent base pairs. (Option B ruled out)

N Base (purine or pyrimidine) attached to pentose sugar (ribose or deoxyribose) by beta-N glycosidic bond. C1 of sugar is linked to N1 of pyrimidine or N9 of purine. (Option C ruled out)

questions.text: Which one of the following sentences is true about circular DNA?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In some organisms, such as bacteria, bacteriophages, many DNA-containing animal viruses, as well as organelles such as mitochondria, the ends of the DNA molecules are joined to create a closed circle with no covalently free ends, eliminating all free 3'- and 5'-termini.
  • This energy-requiring process puts the molecule under torsional stress, and the greater the number of supercoils, the greater the stress or torsion (test this by twisting a rubber band).
  • Circular DNA can adopt relaxed or supercoiled conformations, regulated by topoisomerases. (Option A ruled out)
  • Supercoiling aids in compaction and regulates replication and transcription.

Explanation of other options:

Destroy the polarity of DNA: (Option B) Formation of circular DNA will not destroy the polarity of DNA molecules.

Nuclear DNA is in circular form (Option D): Nuclear DNA is linear DNA, not in circular form. But mitochondrial DNA is circular.

questions.text: The chemical nature of RNA is different from DNA in all of the following except,
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • RNA and DNA both contain the same purine bases (adenine and guanine); this feature does not differ.
  • The chemical nature of RNA is different from that of DNA:
    • RNA is a polymer of purine and pyrimidine ribonucleotides linked together by 3' 5'-phosphodiester bonds analogous to those in DNA.
    • Although sharing many features with DNA, RNA possesses several specific differences in sugar, pyrimidine N base, alkali hydrolysis, etc

questions.text: The retroviruses (eg, HIV) are transcribed by reverse transcriptase enzymes to produce a double-stranded DNA copy of their RNA genome. This viral reverse transcriptase enzyme is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Retroviral reverse transcriptase uses the RNA genome as a template to synthesise a complementary DNA strand; hence, it is an RNA-dependent DNA polymerase.
  • The resulting double-stranded DNA integrates into the host genome as a proviral DNA, serving as a template for viral mRNA and genome synthesis.
  • Genomic insertion of such integrating "proviral" DNA molecules can, depending on the site involved, be mutagenic, inactivating a gene or dysregulating its expression.
  • The genetic material for some animal and plant viruses is RNA rather than DNA.
  • Many animal RNA viruses, specifically, the retroviruses (eg, the human immunodeficiency virus, or HIV), are transcribed by viral RNA-dependent DNA polymerase, the so-called reverse transcriptase, to produce a double-stranded DNA copy of their RNA genome.

questions.text: Almost all eukaryotic mRNA molecules, at the 3'-hydroxyl terminus, have an attached, non genetically encoded polymer of adenylate residues, which is known as the poly(A) tail. Such poly (A) chains are present in all mRNA that code for different proteins, except mRNA that codes for:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Eukaryotic mRNAs have unique chemical characteristics.

  • The 5' terminus of mRNA is "capped" by a 7-methylguanosine triphosphate.
  • The cap is involved in the recognition of mRNA by the translation machinery, and also helps stabilise the mRNA by preventing the nucleolytic attack by 5'-exoribonucleases.
  • The protein-synthesising machinery begins translating the mRNA into proteins, beginning downstream of the 5' or capped terminus.
  • At the other end of almost all eukaryotic mRNA molecules, the 3'-hydroxyl terminus has an attached, non genetically encoded polymer of adenylate residues 20 to 250 nucleotides in length.
  • The poly(A) "tail" at the 3'-end of mRNAs maintains the intracellular stability of the specific mRNA by preventing the attack of 3'-exoribonucleases and also facilitates translation.
  • A few mRNAs, including those for some histones, do not contain a poly (A) tail.
  • Both the mRNA "cap" and "poly(A) tail" are added posttranscriptionally by nontemplate-directed enzymes to mRNA precursor molecules (pre-mRNA).

Reverse transcriptase (Option A): This is a viral enzyme whose mRNA comes from retroviruses, and it has a poly(A) tail. Viral mRNAs mimic host mRNAs and are polyadenylated to ensure translation in eukaryotic cells.

RNA polymerase (Option B): The mRNA for RNA polymerase subunits is processed like typical eukaryotic mRNA and has a poly(A) tail. It is transcribed by RNA polymerase II and polyadenylated during post-transcriptional modification.

DNA polymerase (Option C): The mRNA coding for DNA polymerase is a standard protein-coding mRNA and includes a poly(A) tail. It undergoes normal mRNA processing, including 5'capping, splicing, and 3'polyadenylation.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding messenger RNA?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Messenger RNA is the most heterogeneous in abundance, size, and stability. Specific transcriptional and post-transcriptional mechanisms contribute to this large dynamic range in mRNA content.

Function:

  • All members of the mRNA class act as messengers, conveying genetic information from DNA to the protein-synthesizing machinery (ribosomes).

Role in Translation:

  • Each mRNA serves as a template for assembling a specific sequence of amino acids to produce a specific protein, the final gene product.

Posttranscriptional Modifications:

  • The 5' "cap" by 7-methylguanosine triphosphate and 3' "poly(A) tail" are not coded by DNA but are added posttranscriptionally. (Option A & B)
  • These modifications are made by nontemplate-directed enzymes to the pre-mRNA (precursor mRNA).

Proportion of Cellular RNA:
 mRNA makes up only 2-5% of the total RNA in eukaryotic cells.

Pre-mRNA Processing in Mammals:

  • In mammalian cells (including human cells), the cytoplasmic mRNA is not the direct product of transcription.
  • Instead, it is derived from pre-mRNA, which undergoes extensive processing before exiting the nucleus.

Size and Complexity of Pre-mRNA:

  • Primary transcripts (pre-mRNA) in the nucleus are often 10–50 times longer than the final mature mRNA. (Option D)
  • They are highly heterogeneous in size and structure before processing.

Maturation Process:

Pre-mRNA undergoes:

  • 5' capping
  • Splicing (removal of introns)
  • 3' polyadenylation
    to become mature, functional mRNA that enters the cytoplasm for translation.

questions.text: The tRNA molecules serve as adapters for the translation of the information in the sequence of nucleotides of the mRNA into specific amino acids. All of the following features are found commonly in all the tRNA molecules, except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The CCA sequence at the 3′ end of every tRNA is added post-transcriptionally by a specific nucleotidyl transferase enzyme, not by a non-enzymatic process.
  • The acceptor arm terminates in the nucleotides CpCpAOH. These three nucleotides are added post-transcriptionally by a specific nucleotidyl transferase enzyme. The tRNA-appropriate amino acid is attached, or 'charged', onto the 3'-OH group of the A moiety of the acceptor arm through the action of specific aminoacyl tRNA synthetases.

Transfer RNA:

  • Length: Typically 74-95 nucleotides
  • Processing: Synthesized as a precursor, then processed in the nucleus like other RNAs.
  • Function: Acts as an adapter that translates mRNA codons into amino acids during protein synthesis.
  • Variety: At least 20 tRNA species per cell - one or more for each of the 20 amino acids. (Option A)
  • Structure:
    • Primary structure: Linear nucleotide sequence.
    • Secondary structure: Cloverleaf form due to intrastrand base pairing.
    • Contains four arms/stems: (Option B)
      • Acceptor arm (ends in CpCpAOH added post-transcriptionally)
      • D arm
      • TψC arm
      • Variable (extra) arm
    • Charging: The correct amino acid is attached to the 3'-OH of the terminal A by specific aminoacyl-tRNA synthetases.
    • Abundance: Makes up about 20% of total cellular RNA.

Explanation of other options:

(Option D) There is intrastrand complementarity in all tRNA molecules, which generates an extensively folded secondary structure that appears in two dimensions like a cloverleaf.

questions.text: The smaller subunit of the mammalian ribosome contains which of the following rRNAs?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • The eukaryotic ribosome splits into a 40S small subunit and a 60S large subunit.
  • The smaller 40S subunit contains a single 18S rRNA
  • 5S, 5.8S, and 28S rRNAs reside in the 60S large subunit.

Ribosomal RNA

  • A ribosome is a cytoplasmic nucleoprotein structure that acts as the machinery for the synthesis of proteins from the mRNA templates. On the ribosomes, the mRNA and tRNA molecules interact to translate the information transcribed from the gene during mRNA synthesis into a specific protein. During periods of active protein synthesis, many ribosomes can be associated with any mRNA molecule to form an assembly called the polysome.
  • The 60S subunit contains a 5S rRNA, a 5.8S rRNA, and a 28S rRNA; there are also more than 50 specific polypeptides. (Option A, B, & D)
  • The 40S subunit is smaller and contains a single 18S rRNA and approximately 30 distinct polypeptide chains.
  • Except for 5S rRNA, all other rRNA molecules are processed from a single 45S precursor RNA molecule in the nucleolus.

questions.text: Which of the following snRNAs is involved in the production of the correct 3' ends of histone mRNA, which lacks a poly(A) tail?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

The U7 snRNA is involved in the production of the correct 3' ends of histone mRNA-which lacks a poly(A) tail.

Small Nuclear RNAs

  • snRNAs, a subset of the small nuclear RNAs, are significantly involved in rRNA and mRNA processing and gene regulation.
  • Of the several snRNAs, U1, U2, U4, U5, and U6 are involved in intron removal and the processing of mRNA precursors into mRNA within the nucleus. (Option A, B, and C)
  • The U7 snRNA is involved in the production of the correct 3' ends of histone mRNA-which lacks a poly(A) tail.
  • 7SK RNA associates with several proteins to form a ribonucleoprotein complex, termed P-TEFb, that modulates mRNA gene transcription elongation by RNA polymerase II.

questions.text: Which of the following RNAs is specifically used to decrease specific protein levels?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • The small non-coding RNAs (ncRNAs) termed miRNAs (Micro-RNAs) and siRNAs (silencing RNAs) typically inhibit gene expression at the level of specific protein production by targeting mRNAs through one of several distinct mechanisms.
  • siRNAs are frequently used to decrease or "knockdown" specific protein levels (via siRNA homology-directed mRNA degradation) in experimental contexts in the laboratory.

circRNAs (Option B): There are two classes of larger noncoding RNAs: the circular RNAs (circRNAs) and the long noncoding RNAs, or lncRNAs. While the functions of circRNAs are still being elucidated, they seem to be particularly abundant in cells of the nervous system. Similar to lncRNAs, these molecules likely play important roles in cellular biology by regulating gene expression at multiple levels.

Small Nuclear RNAs (snRNAs) (Option C), a subset of the small nuclear RNAs, are significantly involved in rRNA and mRNA processing and gene regulation.

Ribosomal RNA (Option D): On the ribosomes, the mRNA and tRNA molecules interact to translate the information transcribed from the gene during mRNA synthesis into a specific protein.

questions.text: RNAs are far less stable than DNA due to presence of:
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

RNAs are far less stable than DNA since the 2'-hydroxyl group of RNA (absent in DNA) functions as a nucleophile during hydrolysis of the 3',5'-phosphodiester bond.

  • DNA and RNA are both polynucleotides made of nucleotides linked by 3',5'-phosphodiester bonds, forming the sugar-phosphate backbone.
  • Although hydrolysis of these phosphodiester bonds is thermodynamically favoured, in DNA it occurs very slowly without enzymatic action, allowing DNA to persist for long periods, even in fossils.
  • In contrast, RNA is much less stable than DNA. This is because RNA contains a 2'-hydroxyl (-OH) group on the ribose sugar (which DNA lacks).
  • This 2'-OH group acts as a nucleophile and facilitates the hydrolysis of the 3',5'-phosphodiester bond. Thus, the presence of the 2'-hydroxyl group in ribose makes RNA inherently more prone to breakdown.

choices.text: Used to analyse structure of DNA
DNA rich in G-C pairs melts at lower temperature than DNA rich in A-T pairs

questions.text: Which of the following is true about denaturation of DNA?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Denaturation can be used to analyse the structure of DNA.

  • The double-stranded structure of DNA can be separated into two component strands in solution by increasing the temperature or decreasing the salt concentration.
  • Not only do the two stacks of bases pull apart, but the bases themselves unstack while still connected in the polymer by the phosphodiester backbone.
  • The strands of a given molecule of DNA separate over a temperature range.
  • The midpoint is called the melting temperature, or Tm.
  • The Tm is influenced by the base composition of the DNA and by the salt concentration of the solution.
  • A 10-fold increase in monovalent cation concentration increases the Tm by 16.6°C by neutralising the intrinsic interchain repulsion between the highly negatively charged phosphates of the phosphodiester backbone.

Decrease optical absorbance (Option A): Concomitant with this denaturation of the DNA molecule is an increase in the optical absorbance of the purine and pyrimidine bases, a phenomenon referred to as hyperchromicity of denaturation.

Increase its viscosity (Option B): Because of the stacking of the bases and the hydrogen bonding between the stacks, the double-stranded DNA molecule exhibits properties of a rigid rod and, in solution, is a viscous material that reduces or loses its viscosity upon denaturation.

DNA rich in G-C pairs melts at a lower temperature than DNA rich in A-T pairs (Option D): DNA rich in G-C pairs, which have three hydrogen bonds, melts at a higher temperature than DNA rich in A-T pairs, which have two hydrogen bonds.
